comments.commentBody: Ich bin ein walrus. Goo-goo-gaju...

@sabine - Not enough Americans know what ' king tide ' in October does to streets in not just South Beach, but how much of Matheson Hammock park in the Gables gets submerged/inaccessible on days without a cloud in the sky:

http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/10/03/miami-beach-king-tide_n_5925950...

Looking at submerged South Beach intersections and submerged Gables parkland when it hasn't even been raining illustrates the problem better than just words.
Why go to the beach? If you wait another couple of weeks, the beach will be in your front yard.
You have a laundry room with 12 foot ceilings? Warming aside, personal narratives are often fish stores.

I've lived in Miami for 10 years. About five years ago, when I lived on south beach, we had a rainstorm that lasted for about 3 hours. When it stopped, we wandered out to encounter waist high water in some areas, incredible. Our downstairs laundry room was flooded with 11 ft standing water. Clearly something was stopping up the drainage systems. Then I was informed that the ocean water was flowing into the drainage system, so the downfall had nowhere to go. Twice Ive had my car flooded by parking on the street. Car insurance is high if you live in the 33139 area code. Now when we go to south beach and it has rained, we take our utility truck. Incredible is to see new construction that doesn't account for this. Sandbags along the store entrances after a typical rain In the summer is the norm.

How can you not love a puzzle with GONE TO RACK AND RUIN across the middle. Great phrase I've not heard in years, and I likely read it somewhere rather than heard it said.

I found this a fast solve for a Saturday. I finished off the southeast corner first and the northeast last. I had to get many crosses for MARIONETTE too Deb, so don't feel alone.

Well done Julian and Will.

Get out if you don't want to live there. No one is stoping you. There are planty of people that knows other big cities are far worse. Want to occupy the street in New York? Prepared to the charged by mounted police.
After hearing this, I am so angry too. They are so stupid. They don't even know they can use an ambulance to carry the supply.

Just to fill everyone in on the details. What he was talking about was that the "peaceful" protestors blocked all entrance to the government headquarter. And when police need to bring in supplies, they need to ASK PERMISSION from these peaceful protestors! Now try that in New York, please!

I come from Hong Kong. I am so angry for what the government has done on the citizens. The government has lied to us for a few times this week. 0n 2/10, the police force told us that an ambulance have to enter the goverment building through the crowd, but then it was followed by 2 police cars. The citizens asked why, the police told us that the police need to have rest and let other police to take the duty. The citizens allowed. However, the media later discovered that a large amount of tear gas and rubber baton was transported in. On 3/10, the police stayed reacting slowly to the attacks pn the protestors. I cannot tolerate such a government! It uses such ways with lies and violences to end the movement. Shame on Hong Kong government! Shame on Hong Kong police!
Hand up for HOT before RIB. I even tried BBQ knowing it wouldn't work as it was used in the clue.

Marty C, I was leaning to Belloc, instead of BALZAC @ 55A.

As for this SATXWDP outing by Julian Lim,
"OH YEAH, I really DUG it!"

I've had the same experience in Manhattan. These are phantom plans.  No one decent takes them and when they do, the wait is ridiculously long.  Policitians would never accept this for themselves.
Wondering if the mtg interest is even deductible since I imagine he's liable for the alternative minimum tax.

For most of his guerilla career, Quantrill (and Anderson, and Todd, et al) operated outside of Jefferson Davis' (and/or Lee's) reach, or practical jurisdiction. The guerillas wintered in Texas in 1863-64, but by then the West was essentially "Kirby Smithdom", and outside the control of Richmond authorities. My understanding is, the guerillas wore their welcome out in Texas, also.

Late in the war, and just after, there were some examples of Union and Confederate soldiers (or, in the case of the latter, veterans and/or parolees) cooperating to suppress bushwhackers.

Actually, the more pertinent Barbara Tuchman book would be, "Stilwell and the American Experience in China." That book describes the billions of dollars spent training and equipping Chiang Kai-shek's armies during the Second World War, Chiang's refusal to use them to fight the Japanese, the ire Stilwell expressed at the stupid waste, and the collapse of those armies once they were actually used for their intended purpose -- to fight the Communists.

What happened then between Chiang and the U.S. -- his reliance with and romance of right wing Republicans, for example, his manipulation of domestic U.S. politics with the connivance of Henry Luce, Chiang's fecklessness, the corruption of his regime, if not Chiang personally, and the inability of his army to fight the much more poorly trained and equipped Communists -- has served as the paradigm for U.S. puppet militaries ever since -- Bay of Pigs Cuban invaders, Diem, Key, Thieu, Karzai, Jaffari, Maliki and many others.

It is the cautionary tale of the puppet using contacts with Republicans -- Thieu and Nixon's connivance to torpedo the Paris peace talks, for example -- to allow the nominal puppet to manipulate and exploit the nominal puppeteer.

The folly of attempting to use puppet troops to shore up the farther reaches of the empire.

And the folly of empire.
So of course, to justify its wars, our government wants us fed a constant diet of how "they" are savage towards us, but Americans are to be kept in the dark how we are savage towards them.

Nuri al-Maliki:  What a disaster!  He and his henchmen make South Vietnam's Ngo Dinh Diem look like a genius (which I would have thought impossible....).  Take a trained military and replace all your best officers with toadies and you get ...
How many times has the US military told us they were building armies.....how many times have they collapsed....justa joke....for so much money....often ripped off by US consultants...stop the wars!
Which brings us back to the 28 redacted pages in the 9/11 Report... the redacted pages demonstrating Saudi complicity in the attack on the Twin Towers.

It's painfully obvious that ISIS is the pit-bull unleashed by the Saudis, Qataris, Kuwaitis to "protect" their interests in Iraq and Syria against Iran. If you go back a year or so ago, the Saudis threatened as much if the West did not help them overthrow Assad. The only ones who have the will to fight ISIS are the Kurds but the West is deliberately under-arming them for fear of upsetting the Turks. The Turks are playing coy about joining the fight against ISIS because it is doing their dirty work of weakening the Kurds. Ironically, if we are to win against ISIS, we have to seek the help of the West's old nemesis Iran and also support Assad. But that will be upset it's "friends" the Saudis, Qataris, Kuwaitis et. al.. Can you say witch's brew?
Because it was an article about football.

During the final 25 years of the Big 8 Conference, from 1970-1995, the Big 8 won 8 football national titles (Nebraska '70, '71, '94 '95;Oklahoma '74, '75,
'85; Colorado '90).

The Big Ten won exactly ZERO. (Ohio State claims a share of the national title in 1970, from the Football Writer's Poll, but that's back when some of the polls did their final poll before the bowl games. Ohio State lost to Stanford in their bowl game 27-17. The final AP Poll, conducted after the bowl games, crowned Nebraska National Champions by virtue of their Orange Bowl victory over LSU.)

Penn State won national titles in '82 and '86, but that's back when they competed as an Independent, before they were infected by the mediocrity of the Big Ten.

Since 1995, the Big Ten won 2 national titles, one in '97 by Michigan, which they shared with undefeated Nebraska, and Ohio State's in '02.

So that's 2 national titles in football since 1970.

My point is that the Big Ten has been weak for DECADES. This is not a new thing. It's quite obvious.
Explain self-infantilization, please. Have no idea what you are speaking about.
Culturally sanctioned prolonging of one's own adolescence. Especially as supported by parental indulgence (and its opposite: parental neglect), pop cultural navel-gazing, and nostalgia-pandering.
The issue is not that the author was immature, but that she was iffy about marriage. If marriage means adulthood, then yes, you can say she was an adolescent. But that is not the point here.

While I appreciate the emotional honesty, this piece leaves me thinking about self-infantilization (is that a thing? It should be.) People my age do this a lot. I was surprised by the disclosure that "all of this" happened in her early thirties; prior to reading that, I was picturing flummoxed early-to-mid-20-somethings navigating these perils of adulthood. I'm in my mid-thirties, and people my age manage to keep having children, but we can't quite seem to grow up. Why?

And if Victor and Kennel had said anything like that, that complaint might make a lick of sense.

By the way, it seems that the first carbon capture plant opened in Canada this week.

Oops.

> McKittrick proposes a carbon tax based on observed temperature change. HIgh delta T, high carbon tax. No temp change, zero carbon tax.

The problem with that suggestion is that if high delta T is what plays out then, carbon tax or no carbon tax, there's a good chance we're screwed. And there ain't gonna be any kind of tax or tax break which is going to unscrew things.

The argument for reducing CO2 emission is large part an argument in favor of risk mitigation. As MIT climate scientist Kerry Emanuel put it: "Being conservative in signal detection (insisting on high confidence that the null hypothesis is void) is the opposite of being conservative in risk assessment."
(Link = http://fivethirtyeight.com/features/mit-climate-scientist-responds-on-di... We don't know for sure how things will turn out if we raise the temperature by 2 deg or 3 deg or 5 deg C but there's ample reason to believe that, from the standpoint of sustaining civilization in the manner to which we've become accustomed, things will turn out badly. There's no hedge against that outcome.

Yes, the long debate about climate sensitivity continues with most recent estimates in the 1.5 to 2.0 range. If you are not sure what climate sensitivity is or why it is the important metric, look here-
http://climatesensitivity.blogspot.com/

Dear Andy,

Victor and Kennel's piece advocates ditching the 2 K temperature change goal and substituting, among other goals, simple CO2 emissions goals instead.

That idea is fundamentally flawed.

The climate science researchers are still in heated debate about climate sensitivity. Latest numbers have been steadily coming down from the earlier estimates. HIgh -end estimates of high climate sensitivity, the prophets of doom, are now clearly in error. See Lewis and Curry, Climate Dynamics, DOI 10.1007/s00382-014-2342-y

Until the scientists pin down climate sensitivity, NOBODY knows how much temperature rise or other damage a given amount of CO2 emission will produce.

The only thing that is clear is that the vast majority of climate models overestimate the temperature rise from GHG emissions. Their climate sensitivity is simply too high.

Yet the economic models to predict the cost of emissions are all tuned to the assumption of high climate sensitivity. See Ross McKitrick's latest Fraser Institute paper "Climate Policy Implications of the Hiatus in Global Warming" Oct. 2014.

Until climate sensitivity is better understood, and economic models have been tuned to that new, more realistic climate sensitivity, "carbon taxes" are sure to be unrealistically high.

McKittrick proposes a carbon tax based on observed temperature change. HIgh delta T, high carbon tax. No temp change, zero carbon tax.

Interesting idea.

What if it cools? We get money back? And from whom?

I have no qualms with ev psych, or even with the (very difficult to test) claim that the reason there is more emphasis on women's looks than on men's looks here and now, has to do with innately specified gender differences in sexual selection strategies and mate preferences.

But that in no way explains why fat women would be *shamed* or *mistreated* for being fat, more than fat men are. No one's making these hateful commenters sleep with anyone. The question is why fat women receive so much more *abuse* than fat men. Mate selection has nothing to do with that.

Sweet, Martin. Mellus vanellus.

Great list, DL. All those terms have more intrinsic colour than is readily apparent in the working translations.
Doubtless, the former mayor of Wasilla wasn't in attendance.

Not all of Alaska ignores climate change. Our former mayor and the mayor of Anchorage organized a mayors climate change group that included mayors from Alaska and many other states. I haven't followed it to know whether it is still active, but because of the amount of money that the state and the private sector has been spending to deal with serious damage caused by coastal changes and melting permafrost, it is a topic of serious discussion.

What one office seeker or office holder says in a political context is not worth the time it takes to hear or read it. What matters is what is being done and what the next generation is going to do about it. They are the ones our inability to act will harm, so as they watch their elders dithering and the environment changing more every year, let's hope they are motivated to do what we should have done and expand what some have started to do. Those of us in the generation that failed to act should at least help them prepare.

It is amazing to me that individuals like Mario Rubio or Bobby Lindahl get the idea they have any qualifications to even comment on whether global warming is real. Perhaps after they float out to see and their state has disappeared they "might" consider it was a possibility.

Where did they get their science education? How can they evaluate data they probably haven;t even looked at much less read. What more do they do than Blah! Blah! Blah! which is their form of "chicken Little".

Are we supposed to take these characters seriously?
The last two situations already exist, and the first two aren't far off.
I'd like to disabuse you of taking credit for environmental awareness, that belongs to the 60s.

Interesting, some people still think global warming is a joke, and it's showing up in some of the comments.  When there are no bees and therefor no fruit or vegetables, when we no longer can regulate the rate of our pollution and earthquakes become matter of course for areas deeply involved in fracking, when our drinking water has the ability to also act as a source of light and perhaps also as a fuel because of the chemicals that have seeped into the aquifer, maybe then some people will start to take the environment seriously.  Of course by then, as Ms. Collins has said, we will be the walrus.
People who actually like real football know that it is played in the rain, snow and mud, and cold. Of course that refers back to times when it was a game and not some kind of gladiator blood-sport.

Spoken like a typical Californian.  College football's best years were about schools in the Upper Midwest where they can handle the weather, and a lot more:  Notre Dame (Ara Parseghian), Michigan State (Duffy Daugherty), and U of M (Bo Schembechler), and Ohio State (Woody Hayes).
Weather alone, would make me want to play football in the West or South.

# of recruits required for dominant basketball programs is far less than a football program.  The quality of Big 10 basketball coaches has also been vastly superior to the quality of it's football counterparts.

If cold weather, population decline, regional economic doldrums, etc. account for the decline of Big Ten football, what explains the extremely strong and undiminished position of the Big Ten in the world of NCAA basketball?

That's right, Amy.

You can hire your own police force, fire department, water utility and judicial system.

You can build your own roads, bridges, railroads and internet.

You can develop your own Centers for Disease Control and National Institutes for Health that have contributed mightily to the reduction of disease and discovery of medical cures in the world.

Taxes are just a waste, right.

Taxes are the price of civilization.

We ought to force all humans and 'corporate' humans to pay up instead of allowing them to be deadbeats who skip town on their checks.

Welcome to society.

Tax avoidance and evasion is a complete breakdown of civilization.
